detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section of the Board Resolution is missing key elements typically found in such resolutions, including a record of directors present, confirmation of quorum, and signatures of the directors. While the resolution states the intent to incorporate under ADGM regulations, it lacks the procedural elements to demonstrate proper authorization and execution.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Articles 26-35 (regarding directors' duties and appointment) and Articles 36-45 (regarding shareholders' rights and meetings) implicitly require proper documentation of board decisions.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The Board Resolution should include a section listing the directors present at the meeting, a statement confirming that a quorum was present, the full text of the resolutions being approved, and signature blocks for each director present to evidence their approval. The date of the resolution should also be clearly stated.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: A compliant Board Resolution should include sections for: 'Directors Present', 'Quorum', 'Resolutions (detailed text)', 'Signatures (with printed names and titles)' and a clear 'Date' of the resolution.
detailed_issues.section_text: RESOLUTION OF INCORPORATING SHAREHOLDERS

detailed_issues.red_flag: The resolution mentions incorporating a company under the name of '[insert proposed company name]' (or any other name approved by ADGM Registration Authority). While this is generally acceptable, the resolution should explicitly state that the company name must comply with Article 17 of the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, which outlines the requirements for company names.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Add a clause stating that the proposed company name must comply with Article 17 of the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: We, the undersigned, being the incorporating shareholders, resolve to incorporate a public company limited by shares in the Abu Dhabi Global Market under the name of [insert proposed company name] (or any other name approved by ADGM Registration Authority, in compliance with Article 17 of the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020), in accordance with the applicable regulations and sub-ordinate rules of Abu Dhabi Global Market (the “Company”).
detailed_issues.section_text: [Insert proposed company name]

detailed_issues.red_flag: The resolution states the intention to incorporate a public company limited by shares in ADGM, which is compliant. However, the provided section is incomplete as it only covers the intent to incorporate and doesn't include other necessary resolutions such as approval of the Articles of Association, appointment of initial directors, allocation of shares, and registered office address. The resolution also lacks signatures, which are essential for its validity.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Articles 1-15 (incorporation procedures), Articles 16-25 (constitutional documents requirements), Articles 26-35 (directors duties and appointment), Articles 36-45 (shareholders rights and meetings)
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand the resolution to include resolutions approving the Articles of Association, appointing initial directors, allocating shares, specifying the registered office address within ADGM, and include signature blocks for all incorporating shareholders. Refer to ADGM Registration and Incorporation guidance for templates.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Example additions: "RESOLVED, that the Articles of Association in the form attached hereto be and are hereby approved."; "RESOLVED, that [Name(s) of Director(s)] be and are hereby appointed as the initial directors of the Company."; "RESOLVED, that the registered office of the Company shall be located at [Address] within the Abu Dhabi Global Market."; "RESOLVED, that [Shareholder Name] be allocated [Number] shares at a price of [Price] per share."
detailed_issues.section_text: We, the undersigned, being the incorporating shareholders, resolve to incorporate a public company l...

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section of the Board Resolution only mentions the appointment of officers upon incorporation but lacks details regarding the process, qualifications, and responsibilities of the appointed officers. It also doesn't explicitly state that the appointment is subject to the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Articles 26-35 (regarding directors' duties and appointment, which are applicable to officers as well)
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand the resolution to include details about the officers' roles, responsibilities, and qualifications. Explicitly state that the appointment is subject to the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 and any other relevant ADGM regulations. The resolution should also specify the effective date of the appointment.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT WAS RESOLVED, to appoint the following individuals as officers of the company upon incorporation, subject to the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, with the following roles and responsibilities: [List of officers with their respective roles and responsibilities]. The appointment shall be effective from the date of incorporation.
detailed_issues.section_text: IT WAS RESOLVED, to appoint the officers of the company upon incorporation as follows.

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section title 'Appointment of Authorised Signatory(ies)' is insufficient. A board resolution for incorporation must explicitly state the powers granted to the authorized signatory and ensure it aligns with the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 regarding director duties and delegation of authority.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 30 (Delegation by directors) and Article 31 (Duties of directors).
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should clearly define the scope of authority granted to the authorized signatory(ies), including specific powers related to incorporation, bank account opening, and other relevant actions. It should also state that the authorized signatory acts on behalf of the company and is subject to the directors' oversight and the ADGM Companies Regulations.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT IS RESOLVED THAT [Name of Authorised Signatory] is hereby appointed as an Authorised Signatory of the Company, with the authority to execute all documents, agreements, and instruments necessary for the incorporation of the Company in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, including but not limited to, submitting applications to the Registration Authority, opening bank accounts, and engaging with service providers, all in accordance with the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 and subject to the oversight of the Board of Directors.
detailed_issues.section_text: Appointment of Authorised Signatory(ies)

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section only mentions 'Appointment of Director(s)' without specifying the actual directors being appointed or confirming their acceptance of the role. This is a critical omission as it doesn't fulfill the requirement of formally appointing directors during incorporation.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 26 (regarding appointment of directors)
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should explicitly name the directors being appointed, confirm their consent to act as directors, and specify their roles (e.g., Managing Director, etc.). A statement confirming that the directors meet the eligibility criteria as per ADGM regulations should also be included.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT WAS RESOLVED THAT [Director Name 1] and [Director Name 2] be and are hereby appointed as Directors of the Company, effective immediately. Each Director has confirmed their consent to act in this capacity and meets the eligibility requirements as per ADGM Companies Regulations 2020. [Director Name 1] is appointed as Managing Director.
detailed_issues.section_text: Appointment of Director(s)

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided document section only mentions 'Appointment of Secretary(ies)' without specifying the necessary details regarding the appointment process, qualifications, or responsibilities as required by ADGM regulations. The ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 outline specific requirements for company secretaries, including their appointment, duties, and potential liabilities. This section lacks the necessary information to ensure compliance.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Articles 26-35 (regarding directors' duties, which extend to the proper appointment and oversight of company officers, including secretaries) and Articles 46-50 (regarding compliance and penalties for non-compliance with the regulations).
detailed_issues.suggestion: The Board Resolution should explicitly state the name of the appointed secretary (or secretaries), their qualifications, and a clear statement that they are aware of their duties and responsibilities under the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020. The resolution should also confirm that the appointed secretary meets the requirements for such a position as defined by ADGM regulations.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT IS RESOLVED THAT [Name of Secretary] is hereby appointed as the Company Secretary of the Company, effective [Date]. The Board confirms that [Name of Secretary] possesses the necessary qualifications and experience to fulfill the duties of a Company Secretary under the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 and is aware of their responsibilities and liabilities as such.
detailed_issues.section_text: Appointment of Secretary(ies)

detailed_issues.red_flag: The resolution states that the Company adopts the Articles of Association 'for the purpose of incorporation of the Company in the Abu Dhabi Global Market.' While this indicates the correct jurisdiction, it lacks explicit confirmation that the Articles of Association comply with all requirements of the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Articles 16-25 (Constitutional Documents Requirements)
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should explicitly state that the Articles of Association comply with the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 and all other applicable ADGM laws and regulations.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT WAS RESOLVED that the Company adopts the Articles of Association, which comply with the ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 and all other applicable ADGM laws and regulations, for the purpose of incorporation of the Company in the Abu Dhabi Global Market.
detailed_issues.section_text: IT WAS RESOLVED that the Company adopts the Articles of Association for the purpose of incorporation...

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section only mentions 'Authorised Share Capital' without specifying the amount, currency, or class of shares. This is insufficient for ADGM incorporation. The ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 require specific details regarding share capital.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 17(1)(b) requires the constitutional documents to state the total number of shares the company is authorised to issue and the nominal value of each share.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution must explicitly state the authorised share capital amount, the currency in which it is denominated, the number of shares, and the nominal value of each share. It should also specify the class of shares (e.g., ordinary, preference) and the rights attached to each class, if applicable.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT WAS RESOLVED that the authorised share capital of the Company shall be [Amount] [Currency], divided into [Number] shares of [Nominal Value] each, of which [Number] are ordinary shares and [Number] are preference shares. The ordinary shares shall have the rights as set out in the Articles of Association.
detailed_issues.section_text: Authorised Share Capital

detailed_issues.red_flag: The resolution regarding authorized share capital is acceptable in principle, but the resolution lacks context regarding the class of shares, par value (if any), and rights attached to the shares. This information is crucial for compliance with ADGM Companies Regulations 2020.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 17(1)(b) requires the constitutional documents (including resolutions related to share capital) to specify the number of shares the company is authorised to issue, the classes of shares, and the rights attached to each class.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should be expanded to include details about the class of shares (e.g., ordinary, preference), any par value associated with each share, and the rights, privileges, restrictions, and conditions attached to each class of shares. For example, voting rights, dividend entitlements, and rights upon liquidation should be clearly defined.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: IT WAS RESOLVED that the amount of the authorised share capital of the company shall be [xxxx] USD, divided into [number] shares of [class] shares with a par value of [amount] USD each. The [class] shares shall have the following rights, privileges, restrictions, and conditions: [detailed description of rights, privileges, restrictions, and conditions, including voting rights, dividend entitlements, and rights upon liquidation].
detailed_issues.section_text: IT WAS RESOLVED that the amount of the authorised share capital of the company shall be as follows: ...

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section of the Board Resolution, while not inherently non-compliant, lacks sufficient detail to ensure full compliance with ADGM regulations regarding share capital. Specifically, it doesn't specify the currency, number of shares, and par value per share. This information is crucial for incorporation and must be clearly stated in the resolution.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 17(1)(b) requires the constitutional documents (which this resolution supports) to state the total number of shares the company is authorised to issue and the nominal value of each share.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should explicitly state the currency, total number of shares authorized, the number of shares to be issued, and the par value per share. For example: "IT WAS RESOLVED that the proposed issued share capital of the company shall be as follows: 1,000,000 shares with a par value of USD 1.00 per share, totaling USD 1,000,000."
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: "IT WAS RESOLVED that the proposed issued share capital of the company shall be as follows: [Number] shares with a par value of [Currency and Amount] per share, totaling [Currency and Amount]."
detailed_issues.section_text: IT WAS RESOLVED that the proposed issued share capital of the company shall be as follows:

detailed_issues.red_flag: The resolution lacks specific details regarding the share capital structure. While it states 'The issued share capital shall be structured as follows,' it doesn't provide any information about the number of shares, their nominal value, or the rights attached to each class of shares. This is a critical omission.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Companies Regulations 2020, Article 17(1)(b) requires the constitutional documents (which this resolution supports) to state the number of shares the company is authorised to issue and the division thereof into shares of a fixed amount.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The resolution should explicitly state the number of authorized shares, the nominal value of each share, and any different classes of shares with their respective rights, privileges, and restrictions. For example, 'The issued share capital shall be [Amount] divided into [Number] ordinary shares with a nominal value of [Value] each.'
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: The issued share capital shall be [Amount] divided into [Number] ordinary shares with a nominal value of [Value] each, and [Number] preference shares with a nominal value of [Value] each, with the rights, privileges, and restrictions as set out in Schedule A attached hereto.
detailed_issues.section_text: The issued share capital shall be structured as follows.

detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
Incorporating Shareholder Signature: __________________________

Title: __________________________
Date: __________________________
(Repeat for each incorporating shareholder)

detailed_issues.red_flag: This section, 'Before signing this contract, please make sure:', is a general instruction and doesn't inherently violate any ADGM regulations. However, its effectiveness depends on the content that follows. If the subsequent content contains clauses that contradict ADGM regulations or omits mandatory clauses, it would be a compliance issue. Without the content that follows, it's impossible to determine full compliance.
detailed_issues.law_citation: N/A - This is a preliminary instruction, not a substantive clause.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Ensure the content following this instruction includes all mandatory clauses as per ADGM Employment Regulations and that no clause contradicts ADGM law. Specifically, verify clauses related to termination, end-of-service benefits, and dispute resolution.
detailed_issues.section_text: Before signing this contract, please make sure:

detailed_issues.red_flag: This statement is a reminder to ensure accuracy and proper cross-referencing after modifying the standard contract. While not inherently non-compliant, failure to update cross-references after modifications can lead to ambiguity and potential disputes, making the contract unenforceable in certain parts. The statement itself doesn't violate any specific ADGM regulation, but its neglect can lead to violations.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, general principle of contract enforceability and clarity.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Add a clause explicitly stating that any modifications to the standard contract must be reviewed by legal counsel to ensure compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations and that all cross-references are accurate and consistent.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: To ensure compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations, any modifications to this contract, including additions or deletions of clauses, must be reviewed by legal counsel. The Parties warrant that all cross-references within this contract are accurate and consistent as of the date of execution.

detailed_issues.red_flag: The instruction 'All footnotes are deleted' raises a potential compliance issue. Footnotes in the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template often contain crucial information regarding legal obligations, employee rights, and explanations of specific clauses. Deleting them could lead to non-compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Review the deleted footnotes to determine if the information they contained is essential for compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations. If so, incorporate the information directly into the relevant clauses of the contract or include it as an addendum. Ensure all mandatory information as per the ADGM template is present.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: N/A - Requires review of original footnotes to determine appropriate replacement text.

detailed_issues.red_flag: The instruction to remove all square brackets could lead to the removal of essential placeholders or optional clauses within the ADGM Standard Employment Contract template. Square brackets are often used to indicate areas where specific information needs to be inserted or where alternative clauses are available. Removing them indiscriminately could result in a contract that is incomplete or does not accurately reflect the agreed-upon terms of employment.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Carefully review each instance of square brackets. If the bracketed text is a placeholder, replace it with the relevant information. If it represents an optional clause, determine whether the clause is applicable to the employment arrangement and either retain or remove the entire clause, including the brackets. Do not simply remove the brackets while leaving the placeholder text.
detailed_issues.section_text: All square brackets are removed

detailed_issues.red_flag: The instruction 'This page is deleted in its entirety' within a standard employment contract raises a significant compliance concern. Deleting a page without proper justification and replacement could lead to missing mandatory clauses or create ambiguity in the contract's interpretation. It is crucial to ensure that all required clauses under ADGM Employment Regulations are present and properly addressed.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, general requirement for comprehensive employment terms; ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024)
detailed_issues.suggestion: Instead of deleting the page, review its content. If the content is not applicable, replace it with a statement indicating 'Intentionally left blank' or re-purpose the page to include other relevant clauses or schedules. Ensure that all mandatory clauses as per the ADGM Employment Regulations and the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) are included elsewhere in the contract.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: If the page is not needed, replace with: 'This page is intentionally left blank.'
detailed_issues.section_text: This page is deleted in its entirety

detailed_issues.red_flag: The section title 'DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION' is a standard and necessary section in employment contracts, but the provided content only includes the title and page number ('1.	DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION	4'). It lacks the actual definitions and interpretation clauses, which are crucial for clarity and enforceability. This section should define key terms used throughout the contract, such as 'Employee,' 'Company,' 'Basic Wage,' 'Monthly Remuneration,' etc.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Populate this section with clear and unambiguous definitions of all key terms used in the employment contract. Refer to the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) for examples of commonly defined terms and their appropriate definitions. Ensure all defined terms are consistently used throughout the contract.
detailed_issues.section_text: 1.	DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION	4

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section "3. HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT 5" is incomplete and lacks specific details regarding working hours, break times, and any potential overtime provisions. While the presence of the section heading indicates an attempt to address this requirement, the absence of substantive content raises concerns about compliance with ADGM employment standards.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, which mandate clear terms of employment, including working hours.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand section 3 to include specific details regarding the employee's daily and weekly working hours, break times, and overtime compensation policy. Ensure compliance with ADGM's regulations on maximum working hours and overtime pay.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
3. HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT
3.1 The Employee's normal working hours shall be [Number] hours per day, [Number] days per week, from [Start Time] to [End Time], with a [Duration] break for lunch/prayer.
3.2 The Company may require the Employee to work reasonable overtime, subject to applicable ADGM Employment Regulations regarding overtime compensation. Overtime shall be compensated at a rate of [Rate] or as otherwise required by ADGM law.
detailed_issues.section_text: 3.	HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT	5

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section "4. PROBATIONARY PERIOD 5" is incomplete and lacks the actual terms and conditions related to the probationary period. This is a critical omission as the ADGM Employment Regulations require specific provisions regarding probation, including duration and termination rights during this period.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations (refer to the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) for guidance on required probationary period clauses)
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand section 4 to include details about the probationary period, including its duration (e.g., 3 months, 6 months), the employer's right to extend the probationary period (if applicable and permissible under ADGM regulations), and the conditions under which the employment can be terminated during the probationary period. Refer to the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) for compliant examples.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
4. PROBATIONARY PERIOD
4.1 The Employee shall be subject to a probationary period of [Number] months commencing on the Commencement Date.
4.2 During the probationary period, the Company may terminate the Employee's employment by giving [Number] days' written notice.
4.3 Upon successful completion of the probationary period, the Employee's employment shall continue under the terms of this Contract.
detailed_issues.section_text: 4.	PROBATIONARY PERIOD	5

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section "5. PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT 6" is incomplete and lacks specific details regarding the location of employment. While the heading itself is compliant, the absence of content raises concerns about adherence to ADGM employment standards, which require clear specification of the employee's work location.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The 'PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT' section must include the full address within ADGM where the employee will primarily work. This ensures clarity and avoids potential disputes regarding work location.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: 5. PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT: The Employee's primary place of employment shall be [Insert Full Address within ADGM].
detailed_issues.section_text: 5.	PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT	6

detailed_issues.red_flag: While the section header '6. WAGE AND ALLOWANCES 6' itself doesn't present a direct compliance issue, the absence of specific details regarding wage payment methods, currency, and breakdown of allowances could lead to disputes and potential non-compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations. The ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) provides a structure for detailing these aspects.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, potential violation if wage details are insufficient to ensure fair and transparent compensation as intended by the regulations.

detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
Example: '11. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
11.1 The Employee acknowledges that all intellectual property rights, including but not limited to patents, trademarks, copyrights, designs, and trade secrets, created or conceived by the Employee during the course of their employment with the Company, whether alone or jointly with others, shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company.
11.2 The Employee hereby assigns to the Company all right, title, and interest in and to any such intellectual property. The Employee agrees to execute all documents and take all actions reasonably requested by the Company to perfect and protect the Company's rights in such intellectual property.
11.3 The Employee agrees to keep confidential all information relating to the Company's intellectual property and not to disclose such information to any third party without the Company's prior written consent.
11.4 The provisions of this Clause 11 shall survive the termination of this Contract.'

detailed_issues.red_flag: The phrase "dismissed for cause in accordance with clause 13.2(a) of this Contract" implies a termination process that must align with ADGM Employment Regulations. While the phrase itself isn't non-compliant, the underlying clause 13.2(a) needs careful scrutiny to ensure it adheres to ADGM's requirements for 'for cause' terminations. Specifically, the reasons for 'for cause' termination must be clearly defined and justifiable under ADGM law, and the employee must be afforded due process.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding termination requirements and 'for cause' dismissal conditions.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Review clause 13.2(a) to ensure it explicitly defines 'for cause' termination reasons that are legally sound within ADGM, such as gross misconduct, breach of fiduciary duty, or persistent failure to perform job duties after warnings. Ensure the clause also outlines a fair process for investigation and employee response before termination.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Clause 13.2(a) should be revised to state: 'The Company may terminate the employment under this Contract with immediate effect if the Employee is dismissed for cause. 'For cause' shall mean [list specific, justifiable reasons under ADGM law, e.g., gross misconduct, breach of fiduciary duty, persistent failure to perform job duties after written warnings]. Prior to termination for cause, the Employee will be given written notice of the alleged cause and an opportunity to respond within [number] days.'
detailed_issues.section_text: has been dismissed for cause in accordance with clause 13.2(a) of this Contract.

detailed_issues.red_flag: The clause regarding the termination of previous agreements and the employee's acknowledgement of having no claims against the company related to such termination could be interpreted as a waiver of rights. A general waiver without specific details could be problematic.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, particularly those concerning termination and end-of-service benefits, do not explicitly prohibit such clauses but require fair and transparent termination processes.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Add a clause clarifying that this termination of previous agreements does not waive any statutory rights the employee may have under ADGM Employment Regulations, particularly concerning end-of-service benefits or unfair dismissal claims. Specify that the employee is only waiving claims related to the *specific* previous agreements being terminated, not any rights arising under ADGM law.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: This Contract supersedes all previous agreements and arrangements (if any) between the Company and the Employee relating to the Employee’s employment by the Company which is hereby terminated by mutual consent. The Employee acknowledges that the Employee has no claim whatsoever against the Company in respect of such termination of previous agreements, *provided that this clause does not operate as a waiver of any statutory rights the Employee may have under the ADGM Employment Regulations*.

detailed_issues.red_flag: While the section '1. DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION' itself doesn't present a direct compliance issue, the absence of a clearly defined governing law and jurisdiction clause within this section or elsewhere in the document is a significant red flag. The contract must explicitly state that ADGM law governs the agreement and that ADGM courts have jurisdiction over disputes.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024), requires specification of ADGM jurisdiction for disputes.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Include a clause within the 'DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION' section or a separate 'GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION' section stating: 'This contract shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM). Any dispute arising out of or in connection with this contract, including any question regarding its existence, validity or termination, shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the ADGM Courts.'
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: This contract shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of Abu Dhabi Global Market (ADGM). Any dispute arising out of or in connection with this contract, including any question regarding its existence, validity or termination, shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the ADGM Courts.
detailed_issues.section_text: 1.	DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATION	4

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section "3. HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT 5" is insufficient to determine full ADGM compliance. While the presence of a section addressing 'Hours of Employment' is a positive indicator, the actual content of that section is missing. Without the specific details regarding working hours, overtime, breaks, and related provisions, it's impossible to assess whether it adheres to ADGM Employment Regulations.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically those sections pertaining to working hours, rest periods, and overtime compensation (specific article numbers not available without the full clause content).
detailed_issues.suggestion: The full text of Section 3, 'Hours of Employment,' must be reviewed to ensure compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations regarding working hours, rest periods, overtime pay, and any other relevant provisions. The contract should clearly define the standard working hours, any provisions for overtime, and the employee's entitlement to breaks.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
Example: '3. HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT
The Employee's standard working hours shall be [Number] hours per week, worked [Number] days per week, from [Start Time] to [End Time] with a [Duration] break. Any work performed beyond these hours shall be considered overtime and compensated in accordance with the ADGM Employment Regulations.'
detailed_issues.section_text: 3.	HOURS OF EMPLOYMENT	5

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section "4. PROBATIONARY PERIOD 6" is incomplete and lacks specific details regarding the length, terms, and conditions of the probationary period. This omission could lead to disputes regarding the employee's status and rights during this period.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand this section to clearly define the probationary period's duration (e.g., 3 months, 6 months), the criteria for successful completion, and the consequences of failing to meet those criteria. Include a statement that the employer may terminate employment during the probationary period with a shorter notice period, as permitted by ADGM Employment Regulations.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
4. PROBATIONARY PERIOD
The Employee shall be subject to a probationary period of [Number] months commencing on the Effective Date. During the probationary period, the Company may terminate the Employee's employment by giving [Number] days' written notice. Successful completion of the probationary period is contingent upon the Employee meeting the performance standards set by the Company. The Company will provide regular feedback to the Employee during the probationary period to assist in their development.
detailed_issues.section_text: 4.	PROBATIONARY PERIOD	6

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section '5. PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT 6' is incomplete and lacks specific details regarding the location of employment within ADGM. While the heading is present, the actual terms defining the place of employment are missing.
detailed_issues.suggestion: This section must specify the exact location within ADGM where the employee will primarily work. For example, 'The Employee's primary place of employment shall be [Specific Office Address], Abu Dhabi Global Market, Abu Dhabi, UAE.'
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: The Employee's primary place of employment shall be [Specific Office Address], Abu Dhabi Global Market, Abu Dhabi, UAE.
detailed_issues.section_text: 5.	PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT	6

detailed_issues.red_flag: While the section header '6. WAGE AND ALLOWANCES 6' itself doesn't present a compliance issue, the absence of specific details within this section regarding wage payment methods, frequency, and inclusion of allowances raises a potential compliance concern. The ADGM Employment Regulations mandate clear and unambiguous terms regarding compensation.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding wage payment and record-keeping requirements (details vary depending on specific regulation number, which is not directly extractable from the provided context but is implied).
detailed_issues.suggestion: The 'WAGE AND ALLOWANCES' section should explicitly detail the agreed-upon wage, payment frequency (e.g., monthly), method of payment (e.g., direct bank transfer), and a breakdown of any allowances included in the total wage (e.g., housing allowance, transportation allowance). It should also state that the company will provide a pay statement as required by ADGM regulations.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: 6.1 The Company shall pay the Employee a monthly Wage of [Amount] AED, payable on or before the [Day] of each month via direct bank transfer to the Employee's designated bank account. 6.2 The Wage is inclusive of the following allowances: [List Allowances and Amounts]. 6.3 The Company shall provide the Employee with a pay statement on or around the date of payment, detailing the gross wage, deductions, and net wage, as required by the ADGM Employment Regulations.
detailed_issues.section_text: 6.	WAGE AND ALLOWANCES	6

detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding sick leave entitlements (refer to the regulations for precise article numbers, as they are not explicitly stated in the provided context but are a mandatory element of ADGM employment law).
detailed_issues.suggestion: The full text of Clause 8, detailing the specifics of sick leave and sick pay, must be provided and reviewed to ensure compliance with ADGM Employment Regulations. detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, which require employers to provide various types of leave, including but not limited to annual leave and sick leave. The specific regulations regarding other types of leave will depend on the company's policies and ADGM guidelines.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand this section to explicitly list the types of 'other paid leave' offered by the company, such as compassionate leave, marriage leave, or any other leave beyond the statutory minimums. detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section header '11. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY 9' is insufficient for a comprehensive compliance analysis. It only indicates the presence of a section on Intellectual Property but provides no details about its content. Without the actual clauses within this section, it's impossible to determine if it adequately protects the company's intellectual property rights under ADGM law, specifies ownership, addresses assignment, or includes necessary confidentiality provisions. The '9' at the end of the header is also unclear and potentially a formatting error.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, which mandate fair and reasonable terms, and ADGM Companies Regulations 2020 regarding company assets and rights.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The 'INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY' section must clearly define ownership of intellectual property created by the employee during their employment, including inventions, designs, and copyrightable works. It should also include clauses regarding the assignment of these rights to the company and confidentiality obligations to protect trade secrets and other proprietary information. The section should be reviewed by legal counsel to ensure it is enforceable under ADGM law.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Example: 'All intellectual property created by the Employee during the course of their employment with the Company, including but not limited to inventions, designs, and copyrightable works, shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company. The Employee hereby assigns all rights, title, and interest in such intellectual property to the Company. The Employee shall maintain the confidentiality of all Company trade secrets and proprietary information.'
detailed_issues.section_text: 11.	INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY	9

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section only contains the title 'NON-SOLICITATION 9'. Without the actual content of the non-solicitation clause, it's impossible to determine if it complies with ADGM regulations regarding scope, duration, and enforceability. A non-solicitation clause restricts an employee from soliciting the company's clients, customers, or employees after their employment ends. The absence of the clause's content prevents a full compliance check.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, potential non-compliance with provisions regarding fair and reasonable restrictive covenants.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Provide the full text of the non-solicitation clause. Ensure it is reasonable in scope (e.g., limited to specific clients or employees), duration (e.g., no more than 6-12 months), and geographical area. The clause should be clearly worded and enforceable under ADGM law.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Example: 'During the Employment Term and for a period of [Number] months following the termination of this Contract for any reason, the Employee shall not, directly or indirectly, solicit, attempt to solicit, or assist in the solicitation of any client, customer, or employee of the Company with whom the Employee had material contact during the Employment Term. This restriction shall apply only within the Abu Dhabi Global Market.'
detailed_issues.section_text: 13.	NON-SOLICITATION	9

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided section only indicates the title 'CONFIDENTIALITY/NON-DISCLOSURE' and a number '10'. It doesn't contain the actual clause content. Without the clause content, it's impossible to determine if it complies with ADGM regulations regarding confidentiality, data protection, and non-disclosure agreements. A compliant confidentiality clause is crucial for protecting company assets and information within the ADGM jurisdiction.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding data protection and confidentiality obligations (specific article number cannot be determined without the clause content). Also, ADGM Data Protection Regulations.
detailed_issues.suggestion: The full text of the Confidentiality/Non-Disclosure clause must be provided and reviewed to ensure it adequately protects the company's confidential information, complies with ADGM data protection regulations, and specifies the governing law and jurisdiction as ADGM.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Example: 'The Employee acknowledges that during their employment, they will have access to confidential information belonging to the Company. The Employee agrees not to disclose or use such confidential information for any purpose other than the performance of their duties for the Company, both during and after the termination of their employment. This obligation extends to all information that is not publicly available, including but not limited to trade secrets, customer lists, financial information, and business strategies. Any breach of this clause will be subject to legal action within the ADGM Courts.'
detailed_issues.section_text: 14.	CONFIDENTIALITY/NON-DISCLOSURE	10

detailed_issues.red_flag: The section title 'RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS' is present, but the actual content of the restrictive covenants is missing. Restrictive covenants (non-compete, non-solicitation, confidentiality) are crucial and must be clearly defined to be enforceable under ADGM law. Simply stating the section title without specifying the terms is insufficient.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, which implicitly require clear and unambiguous terms in employment contracts to ensure enforceability.
detailed_issues.suggestion: Include specific clauses detailing the scope, duration, and geographical limitations of the non-compete, non-solicitation, and confidentiality obligations. These clauses must be reasonable and necessary to protect the legitimate business interests of the Company.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
Example: '15. RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS
15.1 Non-Compete: For a period of [Number] months following the termination of employment, the Employee shall not, directly or indirectly, engage in any business that competes with the Company within [Geographic Area].
15.2 Non-Solicitation: For a period of [Number] months following the termination of employment, the Employee shall not solicit any customers, clients, or employees of the Company.
15.3 Confidentiality: The Employee shall maintain the confidentiality of all confidential information of the Company, both during and after the term of employment.'
detailed_issues.section_text: 15.	RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS	10

An entire agreement clause is standard in employment contracts to prevent reliance on prior agreements or understandings not contained within the written contract. detailed_issues.suggestion: Include a standard 'Entire Agreement' clause stating that the contract constitutes the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes all prior agreements, understandings, and representations relating to the employment.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: This Contract constitutes the entire agreement between the Parties and supersedes all prior agreements, understandings, and representations, whether oral or written, relating to the employment of the Employee by the Company.

While pro-rata calculation is acceptable, it must not fall below the minimum statutory requirements.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding annual leave entitlement (refer to the specific article number in the regulations detailing minimum annual leave, which is not explicitly stated in the provided context but is a mandatory provision).
detailed_issues.suggestion: Add a clause stating that the pro-rata calculation will always be subject to the minimum annual leave entitlement as stipulated by the ADGM Employment Regulations. This ensures compliance even if the pro-rata calculation results in a lower amount than the statutory minimum.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause: During the Year in which the Employee's employment commences, the Employee shall be entitled to a proportion of the Employee’s vacation leave entitlement as shall have accrued on a pro rata basis, but in no event shall such entitlement be less than the minimum annual leave entitlement as stipulated by the ADGM Employment Regulations. During the Year in which the Employee's employment terminates, the Employee shall be entitled to a proportion of the Employee’s vacation leave entitlement as shall have accrued on a pro rata basis, but in no event shall such entitlement be less than the minimum annual leave entitlement as stipulated by the ADGM Employment Regulations.

detailed_issues.red_flag: The provided contract section 'On termination of this Contract:' is incomplete and requires further clauses detailing the obligations of both the employer and employee upon termination. This section must include details regarding final salary payment, repatriation (if applicable), return of company property, and any applicable end-of-service benefits as per ADGM Employment Regulations.
detailed_issues.law_citation: ADGM Employment Regulations, specifically regarding termination and end-of-service benefits (refer to the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) for guidance).
detailed_issues.suggestion: Expand this section to explicitly outline the procedures and obligations for both the employer and employee upon termination, including but not limited to: final salary payment, calculation and payment of end-of-service benefits (if applicable), return of company property, cancellation of visas, and repatriation assistance (if applicable). Refer to the ADGM Standard Employment Contract Template (2024) for comprehensive examples.
detailed_issues.compliant_clause:
On termination of this Contract:
(a) The Company shall pay the Employee all outstanding Wages, allowances, and any accrued but unused vacation leave within [Number] days of the termination date.
(b) The Company shall calculate and pay any applicable End of Service Benefits to the Employee in accordance with the ADGM Employment Regulations.
(c) The Employee shall return all Company property, including but not limited to laptops, mobile phones, documents, and access cards, to the Company on or before the termination date.
(d) The Company shall be responsible for cancelling the Employee's visa and providing repatriation assistance to the Employee's home country, if applicable, in accordance with ADGM Employment Regulations.
(e) The Employee shall cooperate with the Company to ensure a smooth handover of their responsibilities.

detailed_issues.compliant_clause: Any notice to be given hereunder shall be in writing. Notices may be given by either Party by personal or electronic delivery, or post addressed to the other Party at (in case of the Company) its registered office for the time being and in case of the Employee, the Employee’s last known address. Any such notice given by letter shall be deemed to have been served at the time at which the notice was delivered personally or transmitted or (if sent by post) would be delivered in the ordinary course of post. For critical notices, including but not limited to termination or disciplinary actions, electronic delivery must include a read receipt or acknowledgement of receipt. The Parties may also utilize the ADGM portal for official communication where applicable. For the avoidance of doubt, the Parties may agree to any alternative form of delivery of written notices, provided such alternative method ensures demonstrable proof of delivery.
